Hi Potin, I think some more justification of the strategy is required. Otherwise I've made a suggestion that feels cleaner to me.
I'm not convinced that the data should change across those two events. I'll defer to one of the other dbus-sensors maintainers.

IMO, the core problem stems from the commit below going waaaaaay beyond what it should, destroying sensor objects on a power cycle:

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/commit/cafd72f6b9ebb6d3be02a8733489a7221d339e18

The sensor object itself, and the dbus entries should ALWAYS instantiate, regardless of the power state.  Turning the power on/off shouldn't create/destroy the sensor itself, it should only modify the underlying interfaces on the activate() call.  If we need an activate() call, it needs to be handled from within the sensor object, so that when we destroy it on a config change, it does the right thing.


This code needs to be

// destroy the old sensor
sensor = nullptr;

// Create the new sensor.
sensors[sensorName] = std::make_shared<PSUSensor>(...)


This line needs to go away, and become just "sensor->activate()"
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blame/16d6f17bec38b6c095dfb6bed224f17d941fb9b3/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#L1191

Then PSUSensor itself should be internally consistent that it can cancel outstanding operations and restart them (including if it require reiniting the device).

Will changing the createSensors to an activate call fix the double activate call issue?  We're passing activateOnly as true, so what should be happening in createSensors is just another activate.  We could add a loop like what we're doing just below for deactivate, and check the readState for each sensor and decide if we want to activate it.  That said it's likely best/easiest to check for isActive() before trying to activate.

If a sensor is already activated. Why deactivate and then activate it again?

The deactive() task should be powerStateChanged responsible for, right?

The powerStateChanged() callback will deactivate a sensor if it's not in their power state.
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#L1199
@Yung-sheng can you explain your comment. My suggestion was to make activate() more  robust, i.e. do not crash if it is called more than once.

> We're passing activateOnly as true, so what should be happening in createSensors is just another activate.

It may need to be refactored not to use createSensors() API to do activateOnly. But call sensor->activate explicitly. 

Activate still need to be updated to prevent crash when it is called twice.
Done, change to only do `sensor->activate()` when power state change.
Done, add check inside activate().

@Zhikui Ren
I think the activate/deactivate is base on the power state.
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/43847a8c61887dba6f0904e5cfb148e3fb360c1d/src/Utils.hpp#L53

And a psusensor is activate() at createSensors(base on its power state config):
1. boost::asio::post()
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/43847a8c61887dba6f0904e5cfb148e3fb360c1d/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#L1228
2. powerStateChanged()

If a sensor's power state equals power off, powerStateChanged() will deactivate it.
And after hit power on, the powerStateChanged() will activate it again.

Is there any probability a sensor in activate state and we want to activate it again?

> 
> If a sensor's power state equals power off, powerStateChanged() will deactivate it.
> And after hit power on, the powerStateChanged() will activate it again.
>
> Is there any probability a sensor in activate state and we want to activate it again? 

From  API usage perspective, your description is correct. But from an API design perspective, the function activate/deactivate should be handle being called more than once in a row gracefully.
Why are these changes, there could be new sensors need to be created when powerState changed to be on

Hi Zhikui, I added the modification here base on Ed's comment.

> This line needs to go away, and become just "sensor->activate()"
> https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blame/16d6f17bec38b6c095dfb6bed224f17d941fb9b3/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#L1191
>
>Then PSUSensor itself should be internally consistent that it can cancel outstanding operations and restart them (including if it require reiniting the device).


Did I misunderstand the meaning?

But that is only when all the changes Ed mentioned are done.

> IMO, the core problem stems from the commit below going waaaaaay beyond what it should, destroying sensor objects on a power cycle:
>
> https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/commit/cafd72f6b9ebb6d3be02a8733489a7221d339e18
>
> The sensor object itself, and the dbus entries should ALWAYS instantiate, regardless of the power state. Turning the power on/off shouldn't create/destroy the sensor itself, it should only modify the underlying interfaces on the activate() call. If we need an activate() call, it needs to be handled from within the sensor object, so that when we destroy it on a config change, it does the right thing.
>
> This code needs to be
>
> // destroy the old sensor
> sensor = nullptr;
>
> // Create the new sensor.
> sensors[sensorName] = std::make_shared<PSUSensor>(...)

All these need to be done before this line can just be activate
code updated, please have a review.

> The sensor object itself, and the dbus entries should ALWAYS instantiate, regardless of the power state.

This is the key and precondition of only doing activate/deactivate for power state change in @Ed suggestion. The patchset still does not do this because sensors are only created if the hwmonPath is created, i.e. the driver is activated. 
Please see:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69162/7/src/PSUSensorMain.cpp#b300
So if there are devices requires power state to be on, this patchset will break them causing those sensors not created sometime.

A cleaner way is to always create sensors that require power to be on even if hwmon path is not found. This can happen if the driver probe only works when power is on and createSensor is called during power is off.
Build failed. Please fix
this duplicates line 941 - probably a merge mistake
Is the original issue still a problem after this change: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/74727
